query: I need a filtration bank for a flour mill exhaust system. The application is high-risk due to explosive wheat dust, classified as ATEX Zone 22. Total airflow is 15,000 mÂ³/h. We have a fixed height limit of 1,500 mm on the installation platform, but width is not a problem. Material: Galvanized (FZ). Please recommend the GDB assembly and specific requirements.

turns.content: I need a filtration bank for a flour mill exhaust system. The application is high-risk due to explosive wheat dust, classified as ATEX Zone 22. Total airflow is 15,000 mÂ³/h. We have a fixed height limit of 1,500 mm on the installation platform, but width is not a problem. Material: Galvanized (FZ). Please recommend the GDB assembly and specific requirements.

For the flour mill exhaust system, I have configured a GDB-1800x900 filter housing with dimensions 1800x900mm to handle the 15,000 mÂ³/h airflow. The system will be installed in an environment with Particulate Exposure and Explosive Atmosphere. The presence of an Explosive Atmosphere means all components must be grounded to prevent static discharge, and standard filter media must be replaced with anti-static media.To finalize the configuration, I need to know which housing length you need:

clarification.question: Which housing length do you need?

gemini.explanation: The system correctly identifies the safety requirements for an ATEX Zone 22 application (grounding, anti-static media) and correctly asks for the missing housing length. However, it fails critically on product sizing: it recommends a GDB 1800x900 unit for 15,000 mÂ³/h, whereas the catalog rates this size for only 9,000 mÂ³/h. The correct size fitting the height limit would be GDB 1800x1500.

dimension_explanations.correctness: The system claims GDB 1800x900 handles 15,000 mÂ³/h, but the PDF (p.6) lists its capacity as 9,000 mÂ³/h.
dimension_explanations.completeness: The system correctly asks for the missing housing length parameter required to finalize the part number.
dimension_explanations.safety: Undersizing a filter housing by 40% in an explosive dust environment creates dangerous face velocities and pressure drops, risking filter collapse or static buildup.
dimension_explanations.reasoning_quality: The engineering logic for ATEX is sound, but the sizing logic is fundamentally flawed, missing the correct size (1800x1500) that fits the constraints.
dimension_explanations.constraint_adherence: Violates the product's airflow capacity limits significantly.

strengths: Correctly identifies ATEX Zone 22 risks (need for grounding and anti-static media)
Correctly identifies that housing length is a missing parameter
weaknesses: Critical sizing error: Recommended unit is undersized by 40%
Failed to select the valid size (1800x1500) that meets both airflow and height constraints
pdf_citations: GDB lengths: 550 mm or 750 mm (PDF p.8)

content_segments.text: Here is the configuration for your flour mill application.
This configuration requires a mechanical filter to capture particulate from Particulate Exposure. The selected GDB housing is suitable for this purpose.

The system will also be installed in an Explosive Atmosphere (ATEX Zone 22). Explosive atmospheres require all components to be electrostatically grounded to prevent spark ignition. Static charge on ungrounded filter housings can produce sparks exceeding the minimum ignition energy of many dust/gas mixtures. Grounding/earthing of all metallic housing components is required to prevent static discharge.
The housing corrosion class is C2.
**Note**: Explosive atmosphere (ATEX zone) requires all components to be electrostatically grounded to prevent spark ignition. Consider products with this trait

**Note**: Explosive atmospheres require all components to prevent ignition sources. Static charge on ungrounded filter housings can produce sparks exceeding the minimum ignition energy of many dust/gas mixtures. MANDATORY REQUIREMENTS: (1) Grounding/earthing of all metallic housing components to prevent static discharge; (2) Anti-static filter media with conductive fibers or grounding strips â€” standard filter media is NOT suitable for ATEX zones; (3) Equipotential bonding between all housing sections; (4) Compliance with EN 60079-0 (general requirements) and EN 60079-31 (dust ignition protection). For Zone 22 (combustible dust): equipment must meet minimum Category 3D protection level. Non-negotiable â€” follow engineering recommendation
